svt_i2c_master_transaction Class Reference

Inheritance diagram for class svt_i2c_master_transaction:

List of all members.

Detailed Description

This class represents data transaction for I2C VIP and used by the svt_i2c_master_agent.

This class is also used directly by monitor to construct the response object.

Member Function Documentation

  function svt_pattern
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::allocate_pattern
 (   ) 

This method allocates a pattern containing svt_pattern_data instances for all of the primitive data fields in the object. The svt_pattern_data :: name is set to the corresponding field name, the svt_pattern_data :: value is set to 0.

Return values - An svt_pattern instance containing entries for all of the data fields.

 Superseded functions 
 svt_sequence_item_base :: allocate_pattern

  function svt_pattern
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::allocate_xml_pattern
 (   ) 

This method allocates a pattern containing svt_pattern_data instances for all of the primitive data fields in the object. The svt_pattern_data :: name is normally set to the corresponding field name, the svt_pattern_data :: value is normally set to 0. For fields which are displayed but not owned, the method puts the current value in for svt_pattern_data :: value.

Return values - An svt_pattern instance containing entries for all of the fields required for XML output of the data object.

  function bit
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::do_is_valid
 (  bit silent = 1, int kind = RELEVANT  ) 

Checks to see that the data field values are valid.

silent - bit indicating whether failures should result in warning messages.

kind - This int indicates the type of is_avalid check to attempt. Only supported kind value is svt_sequence_item_base :: COMPLETE, which results in verification that the non-static data members are all valid. All other kind values result in a return value of 1.

  function bit
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::get_prop_val
 (  string prop_name , ref bit [1023:0] prop_val , input int array_ix , ref svt_sequence_item_base data_obj  ) 

HDL Support: For read access to public data members of this class. This method is used by a component's command interface, to allow command code to retrieve the value of a single named property of a data class derived from this class. If the prop_name argument does not match a property of the class, or if the array_ix argument is not zero and does not point to a valid array element, this function returns '0'. Otherwise it returns '1', with the value of the prop_val argument assigned to the value of the specified property. However, If the property is a sub-object, a reference to it is assigned to the data_obj (ref) argument. In that case, the prop_val argument is meaningless. The component will then store the data object reference in its temporary data object array, and return a handle to its location as the prop_val argument of the get_data_prop task of the component. The command testbench code must then use that handle to access the properties of the sub-object.

prop_name - The name of a property in this class, or a derived class.

prop_val - A ref argument used to return the current value of the property, expressed as a 1024 bit quantity. When returning a string value each character requires 8 bits so returned strings must be 128 characters or less.

array_ix - If the property is an array, this argument specifies the index being accessed. If the property is not an array, it should be set to 0.

data_obj - If the property is not a sub-object, this argument is assigned to null. If the property is a sub-object, a reference to it is assigned to this (ref) argument. In that case, the prop_val argument is meaningless. The component will then store the data object reference in its temporary data object array, and return a handle to its location as the prop_val argument of the get_data_prop task of the component. The command testbench code must then use that handle to access the properties of the sub-object.

Return values - A single bit representing whether or not a valid property was retrieved.

 Superseded functions 
 svt_sequence_item_base :: get_prop_val 
 svt_sequence_item :: get_prop_val 
 svt_i2c_transaction :: get_prop_val

  function string
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::psdisplay_short
 (  string prefix = "", bit hdr_only = 0  ) 

Returns a string (with no line feeds) that reports the essential contents of the packet generally necessary to uniquely identify that packet.

prefix - (Optional: default = "") The string given in this argument becomes the first item listed in the value returned. It is intended to be used to identify the transactor (or other source) that requested this string. This argument should be limited to 8 characters or less (to accommodate the fixed column widths in the returned string). If more than 8 characters are supplied, only the first 8 characters are used.

hdr_only - (Optional: default = 0) If this argument is supplied, and is '1', the function returns a 3-line table header string, which indicates which packet data appears in the subsequent columns. If this argument is '1', the prefix argument becomes the column label for the first header column (still subject to the 8 character limit).

 Superseded functions 
 svt_sequence_item :: psdisplay_short 
 svt_i2c_transaction :: psdisplay_short

  function bit
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::save_object_begin
 (  svt_xml_writer writer  ) 

This method writes the object begin information in to indicated XML/FSDB file. This method relies on the 'get_pa_obj_data'method to obtain the object information. Therefore the preferred mechanism for altering the format is to overload the get_pa_obj_data to change default object begin information.

writer - Object which takes care of the basic write operations.

Return values - Indicates success (1) or failure (0) of the save.

Therefore the preferred mechanism for altering the format is to overload the allocate_xml_pattern to define a different pattern.

 Superseded functions

  function bit
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::save_prop_vals_to_xml
 (  svt_xml_writer writer , string object_block_desc = "", string prefix = ""  ) 

This method writes the property values to the indicated XML/FSDB format. This method relies on the allocate_xml_pattern method to obtain the pattern for the property values to be saved. Therefore the preferred mechanism for altering the format is to overload the allocate_xml_pattern to define a different pattern.

writer - Object which takes care of the basic write operations.

object_block_desc - String that is placed in the 'object' block created for the data object. If not specified method relies on get_pa_obj_data method to get 'svt_pa_object_data' which will contain the object header information.

prefix - String to be placed at the beginning of each line in the file.

Return values - Indicates success (1) or failure (0) of the save.

 Superseded functions 
 svt_sequence_item_base :: save_prop_vals_to_xml 
 svt_sequence_item :: save_prop_vals_to_xml 

  function bit
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::set_prop_val
 (  string prop_name , bit [1023:0] prop_val , int array_ix  ) 

HDL Support: For write access to public data members of this class. This method is used by a component's command interface, to allow command code to set the value of a single named property of a data class derived from this class. This method cannot be used to set the value of a sub-object, since sub-object consruction is taken care of automatically by the command interface. If the prop_name argument does not match a property of the class, or it matches a sub-object of the class, or if the array_ix argument is not zero and does not point to a valid array element, this function returns '0'. Otherwise it returns '1'.

prop_name - The name of a property in this class, or a derived class.

prop_val - The value to assign to the property, expressed as a 1024 bit quantity. When assigning a string value each character requires 8 bits so assigned strings must be 128 characters or less.

array_ix - If the property is an array, this argument specifies the index being accessed. If the property is not an array, it should be set to 0.

Return values - A single bit representing whether or not a valid property was set.

 Superseded functions 
 svt_sequence_item_base :: set_prop_val 
 svt_sequence_item :: set_prop_val 
 svt_i2c_transaction :: set_prop_val 

Member Attribute Documentation

 rand bit  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::abort_if_arb_lost = 0

Specifies if Master has to dump the current transaction
or retry if it loses arbitration.
  • 1 : Dump the current transaction.
  • 0 : Retry to complete the current transaction

 int unsigned  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::ABORT_IF_ARB_LOST_OFF_wt = 1

Used to control the relative frequency of aborting transfer when arbitration lost produced by randomization with the reasonable_abort_if_arb_lost constraint.

 int unsigned  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::ABORT_IF_ARB_LOST_ON_wt = 0

Used to control the relative frequency of retrying transfer when arbitration lost produced by randomization with the reasonable_abort_if_arb_lost constraint.

 svt_xml_writer  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::active_writer = null

Temporary variable used to hold onto the XML writer currently being used for XML generation. Only valid within call to save_prop_vals_to_xml.

 rand bit  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::arbitrate = 0

Specifies that Master has to arbitrate for the current transaction.
If this configuration parameter is set, Master waits till a START condition is
generated on the bus by other Master on the bus then start the received transaction.
NOTE : If this configuration parameter is set when only single MasterBFM is present in
the environment, causes the sequence to hang.
  • 1 : Wait for START condition before Starting the next transaction on the bus.
  • 0 : Does not wait for START from another Master to start the next transaction.

 int unsigned  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::ARBITRATE_OFF_wt = 1

Used to control the relative frequency of arbitration from master produced by randomization with the reasonable_arbitrate constraint.

 int unsigned  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::ARBITRATE_ON_wt = 0

Used to control the relative frequency of no arbitration from master produced by randomization with the reasonable_arbitrate constraint.

 rand bit [3:0]   attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::clk_stretch_bit_level_pos = 0

This field is used to set directed bit position for clock stretching applicable on each byte, including command byte. For example, if the field value is set to 0, stretching will be applied after the transmission of the first bit of the command/data byte

 rand bit [31:0]   attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::clk_stretch_bit_level_time = 0

This field specifies the stretching time for bit stretching after the selected bit position

 rand bit [31:0]   attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::clk_stretch_byte_level_pos = 32'h0000

Used to select position at which byte-level clock stretching will be done by Master.

 rand int  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::device_id_rollback_iteration = 0

When the master requests for Device ID, according to the frame format as per the protocol, the 3rd byte of the dvice id is followed by a NACK from the master. However, device_id_rollback_iteration can be configured by the user to force an ACK instead of a NACK. This will enable the rollback feature and the slave will keep sending the device id bytes all over again untill a NACK is received on either of the 3 bytes of device id. This variable can be set to any value of n, depending on how many times the user wants to force a NACK on the 3rd byte.

 bit  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::enable_clk_stretch_after_byte = 1'b0

Used to enable/disable clock stretching from Master after every byte transmitted by Master. The clock stretching will be for random number of reference clock cycles and the maximum and minimum range for the random number can be configured through macros SVT_I2C_RAND_CLOCK_STRETCH_MAX & SVT_I2C_RAND_CLOCK_STRETCH_MIN

 rand bit  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::enable_clk_stretch_bit_level = 1'b0

This field enables bit level clock stretching with user defined values of bit position and stretching time

 rand bit  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::enable_clk_stretch_random_bit_level = 1'b0

This field enables bit level clock stretching at random locations of a byte (including command byte) with a random stretching time value

 svt_i2c_master_transaction_exception_list  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::exception_list = null

Object used to hold exceptions for a transaction

 rand bit [31:0]   attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::idle_time = 32'h0001

This is the time interval between completions of a transaction to the start of next transaction for Master.
Time is represented in timescale used (100ps by default).

For reasonable constraint please refer to reasonable_idle_time

 rand bit  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::m_device_id_gen_stop = 0

When the master requests for Device Id, according to the frame format as per the protocol, after the ACK is received for the slave address, a Repeated START is generated by the Master. However, m_device_id_gen_stop can be configured to 1 to force a STOP instead of a Repeated START.

 rand int  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::nack_at_device_id_byte = 0

When the master requests for Device Id, according to the frame format as per the protocol, 1st and 2nd byte of the device id is followed by an ACK from the master. However, nack_at_device_id_byte can be configured to generate NACK instead of ACK. This variable can be configured to any integer value n. In case the rollback feature is not enabled, setting the value of the variable to 3 will not have any effect as the 3rd byte will already be followed by a NACK (as per the protocol).

 rand bit [2:0]   attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::num_of_retry = 3'b001

This count determines the number of time Master will try
to complete the current transaction before dumping it in
case of not getting an ACK from Slave or when it loses arbitration.
Possible values are 1 to 7.

For valid ranges please refer to master_valid_ranges

 rand bit  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::retry_if_nack = 0

Specifies if Master has to abort the current transaction
or retry it to complete if receives a NACK from Slave.
  • 1 : Retry to complete the current transaction
  • 0 : Abort (dump) the current transaction.

 int unsigned  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::RETRY_IF_NACK_OFF_wt = 1

Used to control the relative frequency of not retrying from master produced by randomization with the reasonable_retry_if_nack constraint.

 int unsigned  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::RETRY_IF_NACK_ON_wt = 0

Used to control the relative frequency of retry from master produced by randomization with the reasonable_retry_if_nack constraint.

 rand bit [7:0]   attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::sec_byte_gen_call = 8'h04

This byte is sent as second byte after General Call address is sent on the bus by Master.
Possible Values are :

00000110 (H06)
Reset and write programmable part of slave address by hardware. On receiving this 2-byte sequence, all devices designed to respond to the general call address will reset and take in the programmable part of their address. Precautions have to be taken to ensure that a device is not pulling down the SDA or SCL line after applying the supply voltage, since these low levels would block the bus.
00000100 (H04)
Write programmable part of slave address by hardware. All devices which define the programmable part of their address by hardware (and which respond to the general call address) will latch this programmable part at the reception of this two byte sequence. The device will not reset.
00000000 (H00)
This code is not allowed to be used as the second byte.
Other Values
The remaining codes have not been fixed and devices must ignore them.

For reasonable constraint please refer to reasonable_sec_byte_gen_call

 rand bit  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::send_3_bytes_10b_slv_sr_rd = 0

When this field is configured to 1, the master will send all 3 bytes in case of a READ transaction on a 10-bit address slave. If this field is set to 0, the master will transmit only the Master ID pad, i.e. 7'b111_0XX + W, for next transaction on same slave after a Repeated Start.

 rand bit  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::send_start_byte = 0

Specifies if Master has to send START byte at the beginning of the transaction. Possible values are

  • 1 : Master sends Start Byte
  • 0 : Master doesnot send Start Byte
For reasonable constraint please refer to reasonable_send_start_byte

 rand bit  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::sr_or_p_gen = 0

Specifies if Master has to generate Repeated START (Sr) or a STOP (P) condition after the current transaction
  • 1 : Generates Repeated START (Sr) condition.
  • 0 : Generates STOP (P) condition.
For reasonable constraint please refer to reasonable_sr_or_p_gen

 int unsigned  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::SR_OR_P_GEN_REPEATED_wt = 0

Used to control the relative frequency of repeated start produced by randomization with the reasonable_sr_or_p_gen constraint.

 int unsigned  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::SR_OR_P_GEN_STOP_wt = 1

Used to control the relative frequency of stop produced by randomization with the reasonable_sr_or_p_gen constraint.

 int unsigned  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::START_BYTE_OFF_wt = 1

Used to control the relative frequency of not sending start byte produced by randomization with the reasonable_send_start_byte constraint.

 int unsigned  attribute
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::START_BYTE_ON_wt = 0

Used to control the relative frequency of sending start byte produced by randomization with the reasonable_send_start_byte constraint.

Member Constraint Documentation

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::master_valid_ranges

constraint master_valid_ranges {
    idle_time inside {[0:1000]};
    num_of_retry inside { [0:7]};
    sec_byte_gen_call inside { 8'h04, 8'h06 };
    clk_stretch_byte_level_pos <= data.size();
    nack_at_device_id_byte inside {[0: 50]};
    device_id_rollback_iteration inside {[0: 15]};
    clk_stretch_bit_level_pos <= 8;
    clk_stretch_bit_level_time inside {[ 5000: 10000]};
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_abort_if_arb_lost

Reasonable constraint for abort_if_arb_lost

This constraint is ON by default; reasonable constraints can be enabled/disabled
as a block via the reasonable_constraint_mode method.

constraint reasonable_abort_if_arb_lost {
    abort_if_arb_lost dist {
                             0 :/ABORT_IF_ARB_LOST_OFF_wt,
                             1 :/ABORT_IF_ARB_LOST_ON_wt
                           };
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_arbitrate

Reasonable constraint for arbitrate

This constraint is ON by default; reasonable constraints can be enabled/disabled
as a block via the reasonable_constraint_mode method.

constraint reasonable_arbitrate {
    arbitrate dist {
                     0 :/ARBITRATE_OFF_wt,
                     1 :/ARBITRATE_ON_wt
                   };
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_clk_stretch_byte_level_pos

Reasonable constraint for clk_stretch_byte_level_pos.
constraint reasonable_clk_stretch_byte_level_pos {
    clk_stretch_byte_level_pos inside {[0:data.size()]};
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_device_id_rollback_iteration

Reasonable constraint for device_id_rollback_iteration.
constraint reasonable_device_id_rollback_iteration {
    device_id_rollback_iteration inside {[0:5]};
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_enable_clk_stretch_bit_level

Reasonable constraint for enable_clk_stretch_bit_level
constraint reasonable_enable_clk_stretch_bit_level {
    enable_clk_stretch_bit_level == 1'b0;
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_enable_clk_stretch_random_bit_level

Reasonable constraint for enable_clk_stretch_random_bit_level
constraint reasonable_enable_clk_stretch_random_bit_level {
    enable_clk_stretch_random_bit_level == 1'b0;
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_idle_time

Reasonable constraint for idle_time

This constraint is ON by default; reasonable constraints can be enabled/disabled
as a block via the reasonable_constraint_mode method.

constraint reasonable_idle_time {
    idle_time dist {
                     0 := 1,
                     [1:10] := 100000,
                     [11:1000] := 1
                   };
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_m_device_id_gen_stop

Reasonable constraint for m_device_id_gen_stop.
constraint reasonable_m_device_id_gen_stop {
    m_device_id_gen_stop dist {
                                0 := 1,
                                1 := 0
                              };
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_nack_at_device_id_byte

Reasonable constraint for nack_at_device_id_byte.
constraint reasonable_nack_at_device_id_byte {
    nack_at_device_id_byte inside {[0:20]};
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_retry_if_nack

Reasonable constraint for retry_if_nack

This constraint is ON by default; reasonable constraints can be enabled/disabled
as a block via the reasonable_constraint_mode method.

constraint reasonable_retry_if_nack {
    retry_if_nack dist {
                         0 :/RETRY_IF_NACK_OFF_wt,
                         1 :/RETRY_IF_NACK_ON_wt
                       };
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_sec_byte_gen_call

Reasonable constraint for sec_byte_gen_call

Specifies that the second byte after general call address must be either 8'h06 or 8'h04
This constraint is ON by default; reasonable constraints can be enabled/disabled
as a block via the reasonable_constraint_mode method.

constraint reasonable_sec_byte_gen_call {
    sec_byte_gen_call inside {8'h04, 8'h06};
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_send_3_bytes_10b_slv_sr_rd

Reasonable constraint for send_3_bytes_10b_slv_sr_rd.
constraint reasonable_send_3_bytes_10b_slv_sr_rd {
    send_3_bytes_10b_slv_sr_rd dist {
                                      0 := 1,
                                      1 := 0
                                    };
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_send_start_byte

Reasonable constraint for send_start_byte

This constraint is ON by default; reasonable constraints can be enabled/disabled
as a block via the reasonable_constraint_mode method.

constraint reasonable_send_start_byte {
    send_start_byte dist {
                           0 :/START_BYTE_OFF_wt,
                           1 :/START_BYTE_ON_wt
                         };
  }

  constraint
 svt_i2c_master_transaction::reasonable_sr_or_p_gen

Reasonable constraint for sr_or_p_gen

This constraint is ON by default; reasonable constraints can be enabled/disabled
as a block via the reasonable_constraint_mode method.

constraint reasonable_sr_or_p_gen {
    sr_or_p_gen dist {
                       0 :/SR_OR_P_GEN_STOP_wt,
                       1 :/SR_OR_P_GEN_REPEATED_wt
                     };
  }
